org.projectbarbel.histo

Interface BarbelHisto<T>

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BarbelHistoCore

    public interface BarbelHisto<T>
    The main abstraction of BarbelHisto that provides the client API. Clients should perform all operations with this interface.

    Create an instance as follows:

    BarbelHisto histo = BarbelHistoBuilder.barbel().build();

    Explore BarbelHistoBuilder documentation to learn about the different settings you can choose.

    BarbelHisto tracks two time dimensions:
    - effective time is when a change to a domain object is supposed to become effective
    - record time is when that change was recorded in the system

    Two BarbelModes can be used to manage different types ob objects: BarbelMode.POJO is the default mode and allows you to manage Pojos anotated with DocumentId on the objects primary key. An example: 
     public class SomeBusinessPojo {
    @DocumentId
    private String id;
    ... any custom fields and methods
 }
    The primary key should be business oriented, i.e. personel number, contract numer. Of course, using this pojo mode is the easiest way forward. However, behind the scenes BarbelHisto uses proxying when managing pojos to store the version data with the objects you save. Proxying can become complicated in situations where no default contsructors are available, or access to fields does not follow JavaBeans standard. For that reason there is another mode called BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL. One can change the mode to BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL with the BarbelHistoBuilder.withMode(BarbelMode) method like so: 
     BarbelHisto barbel = BarbelHistoBuilder.barbel().withMode(BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL).build();
    If BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL is used clients have to implement the interface Bitemporal on the type they wish to manage with BarbelHisto. In this mode, there won't be any proxying magic applied to objects. When clients implement the interface Bitemporal they need to declare a field of type BitemporalStamp in the business object type. There is nothing else required than declaring the field. Anything else is managed by BarbelHisto. Here is an example:
     public class SomeBusinessType implements Bitemporal {
    private BitemporalStamp stamp;
    ... any custom fields
    public BitemporalStamp getBitemporalStamp() {
      return stamp;
    }
    public void setBitemporalStamp(BitemporalStamp stamp) {
      this.stamp=stamp;
    }
 }
    In any mode described you clients never have to care about the bitemporal version info. This is completely managed by BarbelHisto.

    Use the save(Object, LocalDate, LocalDate) method to save objects to BarbelHisto. The from/until period you enter here is when the object data should become effective and until it should be effective. Use LocalDate.MAX to express that the object stored is valid until infinite.

    To retrieve data you've stored into BarbelHisto you can use retrieveOne(Query) or retrieve(Query). Use the BarbelQueries for your convenience like so: 
     List result = core.retrieve(BarbelQueries.allActive(pojo.getDocumentId()),
                BarbelQueryOptions.sortAscendingByEffectiveFrom());
    The id you enter in queries is the document id of your business object. In BarbelMode.POJO it is the id annotated mit DocumentId like described previously. in BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL you receive the id by calling Bitemporal.getBitemporalStamp().getDocumentId(). Be carefull when to use retrieveOne(Query). Not every query returns a unique result. If you receive NonUniqueObjectException try retrieve(Query) instead.

    Users should become familiar with all the queries in BarbelQueries.

    Use prettyPrintJournal(Object) to understand the storage of journals and what it means to manage bitemporal data in technical terms.

    Clients that use custim data stores like MongoDB or any other of the type should call BarbelHisto#dump(DumpMode) after processing data with BarbelHisto. To restore the journal later to continue processing bitemporal data use populate(Collection).
    Author:
    Niklas Schlimm

    • Method Detail

      • save

        boolean save(T currentVersion,
             LocalDate from,
             LocalDate until)
        Save objects to BarbelHisto. Creates snapshots of state. Clients can safely continue to work on passed instances.
        Parameters:
        currentVersion - the object state to save
        from - effective date of object state
        until - effective until of the state
        Returns:
        true if successful

      • retrieve

        List<T> retrieve(com.googlecode.cqengine.query.Query<T> query)
        Retrieve data from BarbelHisto using cqengine like queries. Clients want to use BarbelQueries for there convenience here. BarbelQueries can be combined with additional queries from QueryFactory.
        Parameters:
        query - the client query from BarbelQueries and/or QueryFactory
        Returns:
        the returned records, maybe empty, never null

      • retrieve

        List<T> retrieve(com.googlecode.cqengine.query.Query<T> query,
                 com.googlecode.cqengine.query.option.QueryOptions options)
        Retrieve data from BarbelHisto using cqengine like queries. Clients want to use BarbelQueries and BarbelQueryOptions for there convenience here. BarbelQueries can be combined with additional queries from QueryFactory.
        Parameters:
        query - the client query from BarbelQueries and/or QueryFactory
        options - the options from BarbelQueryOptions or QueryFactory
        Returns:
        the result list

      • retrieveOne

        Optional<T> retrieveOne(com.googlecode.cqengine.query.Query<T> query)
        Retrieve data from BarbelHisto using cqengine like queries. Clients want to use BarbelQueries for there convenience here. BarbelQueries can be combined with additional queries from QueryFactory. Throws NonUniqueObjectException when query returns more then one result.
        Parameters:
        query - the client query from BarbelQueries and/or QueryFactory
        Returns:
        the returned object as Optional

      • retrieveOne

        Optional<T> retrieveOne(com.googlecode.cqengine.query.Query<T> query,
                        com.googlecode.cqengine.query.option.QueryOptions options)
        Retrieve data from BarbelHisto using cqengine like queries. Clients want to use BarbelQueries and BarbelQueryOptions for there convenience here. BarbelQueries can be combined with additional queries from QueryFactory. Throws NonUniqueObjectException when query returns more then one result.
        Parameters:
        query - the client query from BarbelQueries and/or QueryFactory
        options - the options from BarbelQueryOptions or QueryFactory
        Returns:
        the returned object as Optional

      • prettyPrintJournal

        String prettyPrintJournal(Object id)

      • populate

        void populate(Collection<Bitemporal> bitemporals)
        Method for clients that use a custom data store. It's recomended to only add complete journals previously created by BarbelHisto. That means only add complete set of versions for one or more document IDs. To achieve this, preferably use this method with version collections produced by #dump(DumpMode) method. That ensures consistent state with intermediate persistence operations to custom data stores. You can also use BarbelQueries.all(Object) to retrieve a complete Journal for a single document id, or use BarbelQueries.all() to retrieve the complete data in one Barbel Histo backbone. However, notice that retrieve(Query) does not clear the backbone. If you try to populate(Collection) items already managed in the current BarbelHisto instance you will receive errors.

        In BarbelMode.POJO (default) you have to pass a collection of BitemporalVersion objects. In BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL mode you can add arbitrary objects that implement Bitemporal.

        Notice that this way of persistence to a custom data store is not the recommended way for BarbelHisto persistence. BarbelHisto is based on cqengine. There are build in on-heap (default), off-heap and disk persistence options. See DiskPersistence and OffHeapPersistence for details.

        Parameters:
        bitemporals - consistent list of bitemporal versions
        See Also:
        https://github.com/npgall/cqengine

      • dump

        Collection<Bitemporal> dump(BarbelHistoCore.DumpMode mode)
        Unloads the backbone into a collection and return that to the client. This method is used when client uses custom data store. Store this collection to the data store of your choice. Use in conjunction with populate(Collection) to re-load the stored versions back into BarbelHisto.

        In BarbelMode.POJO (default) you receive a collection of BitemporalVersion objects. In BarbelMode.BITEMPORAL you receive objects that implement Bitemporal.

        In Pojo mode (default) this method returns a collection of BitemporalVersion objects. Use this collection to store the data and to relaod BarbelHisto in the populate(Collection) method.

        Notice that this way of persistence to a custom data store is not the recommended way for BarbelHisto persistence. BarbelHisto is based on cqengine. There are build in on-heap (default), off-heap and disk persistence options. See DiskPersistence and OffHeapPersistence for details.
        Returns:
        the collection of bitemporals to store into an arbitrary data store
        See Also:
        https://github.com/npgall/cqengine
